text: the deep rooted significance of casual stereotyping does not go both ways on a deeper level because white people were not the ones discriminated against for centuries prior to this. It leaves scars that we still feel SIGNIFICANTLY today. The nerve of you people, as non people of colour, to say that racism no longer exists is unbelievable. You have not grown up as a POC. We face things DAILY that you would never even notice because of the privilege you have grown up with, we just take it as it comes as we‚Äôre used to it by now. Being white will never negatively affect your way of living, how people judge you immediately upon meeting you and your prospects. These are things we are still dealing with all the time but you just don‚Äôt notice, just because the percentage of people that casually throw around racist remarks and slurs has diminished. These are things that will only completely vanish after several generations.
author: Sneha Prakash

We face things DAILY that you would never even notice because of the privilege you have grown up with, we just take it as it comes as we‚Äôre used to it by now. Being white will never negatively affect your way of living, how people judge you immediately upon meeting you and your prospects. These are things we are still dealing with all the time but you just don‚Äôt notice, just because the percentage of people that casually throw around racist remarks and slurs has diminished. These are things that will only completely vanish after several generations.

text: @savannah kavinsky 1.They have certainly been, and they are. sorry but you are awfully ignorant of history and the contemporary world around you. Btw, Slavery and ethnic prejudice has been part of the human life since the dawn of humanity and it has evolutionary roots. 2. Your logic is severely flawed . Racism is defined as "Prejudice, discrimination, or antagonism directed against someone of a different race so as to distinguish him/her as inferior." Thus:  "Discrimination against people based on race" = Racism. So when you say "you can discriminate against white people sure" you technically say that it is racism. The fact that a group of people has or has not been discriminated against "Previously" on a "Grand Scale" has absolutely nothing to do with it. If you are discriminating against a certain group of people solely based on their ethnicity "Today" you are "Racist". Period.  It is rather a cheap and ridiculous justification to say you are not just because no body else have ever oppressed them "on a grand scale" before!!! By your flawed logic, We can't be "racist" against many of the ethnicities around the world. For instance, we need to dig in history to find instances of systematic racism "on a grand scale" against me as a Persian. We have rather been colonizers in history and been colonized too. However, I reckon you would not hesitate to extend your definition of "racism" to me because you see me as a "non-white" (though technically I am a Caucasian). But you try so hard to avoid calling out the very obvious racist remarks towards these people "Only" because of their white skin colour which is ,in fact, the very definition of "Racism".

author: Callan Dixon

text:
Marco Gelderblom That then causes an imbalance of equality and creates an unfair system where one ethnic group in a collective society is being favoured over another based solely on their skin colour. This is institutionalised racism, something that should not be happening and must be taken into consideration and realised. 

In point to create a fair society ALL should be treated equal, no one owes you for being a minority, you are not disadvantaged for being a minority and we should not be treating people as victims if they are to see themselves as part of the collective whole and not the disadvantaged minority like the people who claim to help are currently doing. People must be encouraged that they have the ability to do things themselves and not simply given handouts and special treatment based on skin colour.

I know this seems right for a lot of people but for the world as a whole it‚Äôs a mentality that will do more harm than good in the long term.
author: Alexander The Great

text: @Alexander The Great I agree with most of what you are saying. Unfortunately it does not address the historical facts we are facing. It does not address the reality we are living in. It also does not really have much to do of what I am saying. everybody is equal and should be treated as such, of course. But fact remains that minorities, sub-groups, children, woman etc.  are often disadvantaged.   People with power, groups, nations etc often abuse this power and have done so in the past. You can't deny this. You have to take this into account when you talk about equality. The more power you have over a person or group the more responsibility you have.  Your boss hitting on you is not the same as you doing it in reverse. He has the power to fire you. A man hitting a woman typically has more physical strength and there for we do not except man hitting women. Not a double standard. I am talking about the abuse of power. All of it is wrong. Racism is wrong no matter what. But a majority talking down to a minority is worse. I am commenting on the fact that some people don't seem to understand this.

text:
@Marco Gelderblom k
You may be correct on your point about racism being worse against a minority than against a white person  but that subject is always up for debate with a lot of people. I'm not going to debate that point though. I just wanted to point out in your statement about men hitting women and vice versa, that they are both equally as bad as far as I am concerned. And I understand where you're coming from, in that if a man punches a woman he will typically do more damage than a woman who punches a man. However, a lot of women dont use simple punches to attack a man unless they really know how to punch well. Usually when I've seen a woman attack a man first, they kick full force to the nuts and keep kicking while they pull hair and claw for the eyes. I've seen a 100lb. woman who attacked a man first, put him in the hospital with a ruptured testicle and a severe cornea laceration. Sure, if he would have punched her first  he would put her in the hospital with a broken jaw. Sounds pretty  equal to me. It's just old fashioned gender stereotypes that push the idea that women cant damage men as bad in a fight, so it's obviously worse for a man to hit a woman. We all know in this day and age that women are considered to be equal to men on every level so an attack by one on the other should be thought of as exactly the same thing. If the adage of women being equal to men is considered by society to be universally true then that would mean that a woman is not an underprivileged minority compared to a man and should receive no special status vs. a man, based on just gender alone. If you say that adage isn't true then you just triggered every feminist around the world who says that women are equal to or better than men in every way. But, no one can have their cake and eat it to, so which is it? Are women equal to men in every way or are they not and somehow inferior to us in some way, shape or form and deserving of some special status to help even things out? I'm not asking you to pick one. I'm asking society to pick one or the other and settle the debate instead of flip flopping between both answers whenever it suits societie's, an individual's, or group's need to do so. Also if you're boss  hits you, you call the cops he goes to jail and he usually loses his job and power . If you hit him,he calls the cops and you go to jail. You lose your job and go to jail just like he would if he hit you. A CEO or president is no better than anyone else in the eyes of the law.

text: "Either all of it is okay or none of it is okay" we can't have picking and choosing

text: @Bad Bishop I am talking in general. Generally speaking Men are physically stronger. There will be exceptions and examples where the reverse is true Also. All people are equal but you can not deny there are physical differences and circumstances. We don't live in absolutes where everything is always this or that. If we accept we are all equal you can also embrace the things that make us unique and special. The default is human, every human should be treated equal, fair and just. Because of historical context and the fact that minorities, unique groups etc.  have not always been treated this way we do need to account for that. There is no double standard or having it both ways. Men and woman are equal in every way but physical. I am sure someone will be able to even argue with that. Generally speaking that is how I think it is. Equality is not a math equation... it's a basic human right. I don't know, just my opinion. I am not an expert on any of this.

text: I don't think it's a bad thing that they included this clearly racist tweet. It shows the untold truth that also white people are target of hate speech. What I did not expect was the laughter from the audience. These are mean tweets but there's a line. Sometimes this line has been crossed in this show and you could hear that the audience was upset, like a gasp. This time the guy was way out of line, and if you think that I'm overstating this, think of how they would react if this was about black people or asian people, or jewish people. I would be worried if the audience laughed then.

text: You know there are many people in the comments who just slur unwanted words at the avengers cast without thinking. If you don't like them, avoid watching their flims, avoid videos related to them and etc. Instead, you all just throw hurtful words at them. Would it be nice, if I rammed a brick at your face? No. What if everyone around you called you ugly just because they disliked you. Would you like it? It's good they're ridiculed. If the actors got angry, the trolls would win.
author: Mike Dasik

text:
So answer the question...   Would they have shown it if someone said they "hate black people"

This simple question negates your excuse for the hypocritical Hollywood elite who decide what is politically correct.  Plus the title is "Mean Tweets" not "evil" tweets and nowhere does it call the tweets evil.  Comedy is a safe space for all kinds of jokes to include racial, sexual, sexist ect...  When people like Jimmy Kimmel say that white people can't say disparaging jokes about people of color and then turn and promote jokes about hating white people, this called hypocricy.  Let's not forget the comments he has said about people being sexist...  But a few years back he had segments on his other show with women jumping on trampolines in their underwear.
author: DifficultyLevel Noob

text:
I won't argue about this, I partly agree with you...
But "mean" means "evil". Evil is a little worse, but they're basically the same words.
author: Mike Dasik

text:
"Evil" and "mean" are two completely different words and used in two completely different contexts with the only similarity being both are negative.  

Examples include:  That comment you made about her overbite was "mean".  -  The Holocaust was an "evil" act perpetrated by the National Socialist Workers Party and their Muslim allies.  

See the difference.
author: DifficultyLevel Noob

text: Adoring Fan I wouldn‚Äôt say you triggered me, I‚Äôm just stating what i think would be a more effective form of dealing with it. I hear so many people bringing up black and white people‚Äôs double standards a lot bug they always frame it as ‚Äúif they said that about black people there would be pushback, I hate hypocrisy‚Äù rather then the actual idea that people shouldn‚Äôt group together and hate on any group in the first place. It became stigmatized to say those things about minorities because people pushed back and said enough is enough. People need to start pushing back against all forms of bigotry, including against white people.

author: peter lee

text:
peter lee you have a point that white people can‚Äôt say certain things but the truth is white people have had the freedom to say what they wanted for a long time. I think it‚Äôs time that some of them be quiet.

Black people have never been in any position of power over white people, yet white people now want to complain about racism. There‚Äôs actually no way systematically a black person can be racist to a white person. So someone saying they hate white people is more acceptable because no black person will accept being insulted and marginalized anymore. Just think for a second about how this offended you. Now imagine having to feel this every second of every minute of every hour. White folks are upset. Black folks have BEEN upset.
author: T‚ÄôChill

text:
"There‚Äôs actually no way systematically a black person can be racist to a white person." -T'Chill

"Hating people because of their color is wrong. And it doesn't matter which color does the hating. It's just plain wrong." -Muhammad Ali

Let that sink in
author: IntoTheLionsCave

text:
IntoTheLionsCave I understand what you‚Äôre trying to say. But hear me out. People mistake prejudice and discrimination for racism. There are aspects but it‚Äôs not the same.

Racism is both an individual and institutional thing. Black people cant be racist because we don‚Äôt stand to benefit from a system like that. Only white people can be racist to such an extent. I will agree with you on this, it needs to stop white people need to cut out the racism, and black people need to be able to move on from that and do better than be discriminatory towards others.
author: T‚ÄôChill

text: T‚ÄôChill but it's also not fair that white people are punished for what their ancestors did. Both white and black people face racism, but it is true that white people are told that they have no idea what racism is. All those jokes about someone being "white" if they're too scared to do something, or are happy/emotional are racist to both, yet there's nobody talking about rude comments toward white people. And before anyone asks, no I'm not white
author: Ms. Home Arya

text: And I do understand the amount of actual dangerous racism black people face, but the jokes about white people are also not okay. Like someone else commented discrimination of ANY color is not ok. Thank you for keeping this debate civil
author: Ms. Home Arya

text: Ms. Home Arya you‚Äôre right that we all need to stop the discrimination. The only way things will work is if we work together. Thank you for being civil with this topic as well. I appreciate it.
author: T‚ÄôChill

text: Why are you so obsessed with black people? You could have mentioned any other race. People would be equally as triggered if the tweet mentioned Hispanics or Arabs, yet you singled out black people. Why? Careful, your prejudice is showing...

text:
+T'Chill and +Ms. Home Arya

MyZ001 well if you wanna get all race political, you realize that tweet almost certainly came from a black man or woman.

I wouldn't say it was a compliment(though the beginning clearly was) but also not an insult. It was mostly an observation that Chadwick isn't a name black parents tend to give their children, and 9 times out of 10 a Chadwick would be white.

If you were called to come in for a job interview with Latisha you wouldn't expect to meet a Japanese lady. You wouldn't expect a Klaus to be Indonesian, and so on.

It's not impossible, just unlikely.

text:
Here's a little constructive pushback against both sides of this. Humour can fail and be disrespectful and still be a worthwhile enterprise. It frequently does, in fact. The idea of hating someone's acting so much that you would generalise to a hatred of their race is a potentially funny joke, with the target being the idiocy of the idea that anyone would think that's a reasonable way to act. 
The problem is that that joke wouldn't have been broadcast or have met with this kind of positive reception if it had been any other race.

text:
The Balloon Jin Lets Go In BST You know, slavery and adjacent superiority complex/racism existed in many nations  across the globe throughout centuries. To suggest racist behaviuor is displayed mainly in white/black relations of  the U.S is just unapologetically ignorant. Perhaps you should grab a history book instead of reading some BuzzFeed articles.

Besides, insinuating that only white people are cappable of racist behaviour, such an abhorrent and detestable trait, is in itself a sign of prejudice, therefore - racism.

How about this revoliutionary theory - everyone of any race is cappable of racist behaviour, and as an enlightened society we ought to treat such vile manifestations with the same disgust in any case WHATSOEVER. Personally i find it quite justful.

text:
Andrew, actually white European culture got rid of slavery, well at least in it's political sphere.   The whole world practiced slavery and the word slave was derived from the word slav, which was the Slavic people's of Europe (eastern)  which today would constitute Czech's Pole's and Slovaks.   So people of white heritage, so yes all peoples at one time were slaves, it's not a racial issue.   In fact it was a economic issue, people with money bought slaves worked them to death and bought more to make profit for themselves.   If you look at slavery in the west though slaves were treated like property and were fed, housed and taken care of better than in a lot of other places.  Even back then there was more value placed on human lives than in other cultures.  

       It's why i think eventually English gov't started paying slave owners for their slaves, set them free  and banned slavery all together.   USA also banned it along with most European cultures far before other cultures did.   Keep in mind also that been a economic issue as well as a social issue, people with money lobbied gov'ts to enforce slavery laws on their behalf.   Sound familiar?   Corporations (which are a gov't created entity with rights above average individuals) lobbying gov'ts for their interests.   

      However you will never be taught the dangers of gov't in schools that are funded by gov't, it would be like Coke running a school and teaching you the dangers of sugar.   Hence in today's schools the narrative is white oppression and the patriarch.  This serves to undermine our culture create guilt and have us fund corporate / gov't  interests.

         This narrative also helps the corporations in my opinion.   You have the corporate military industrial complex paid by tax payers destroying other cultures/ countries  around the world and then institutions like the UN and EU demanding countries take in refugee's. These institutions are directly linked to groups like the Council of Foreign Relations and many of our gov't officials have served on their boards.     White shame is then used to extort the west's money to populate their countries with more people which may also result in conflicting cultural value systems.   Now corporations have more cheap labor at hand and gov'ts to a certain extent have more cattle to tax and don't forget who the gov't works for.....people who lobby them, not you the tax payer.   The corporations will also have more people to buy their products.  This influx of immigration however is payed for by tax payer money.

      You see it's not about races VS race and how whites are opressor's.   It's about money and consumerism.   Don't get me wrong i am all for business, i would rather deal with people in a business situation than with a gov't agent who won't think twice about throwing me in jail if i don't give him money.   It's when you mix ultimate power (gov't) with billionaires, they end up creating large institutions that run society between the two of them and the rights of individuals are secondary to these institutions.   The irony of it is, the answer to this problem is a gov't that has VERY limited powers and a strong free competitive market place.  You just have to understand that gov't will always become corrupt just as no business person is above corruption either.   Corruption in the market place however can deal a swift blow however, your sales can tank fast.  

       I will stop there, you probably stopped reading few paragraphs ago lol.  Oh one more thing, as cultural differences get worse gov't will have to enact new laws / poower's to themselves to fix the tensions between clashing cultural value systems.   If you noticed both gov't and corporations are acting in tandem and are putting in place laws like hate speech and in some countries compelled speech, a lot of censorship is taking place in both corporate arena's and govt.   It's why i hate the narrative you stated above as it's divisive untrue and hurts individual rights and helps the corporately run fascist gov't.   That is one aspect of fascism btw, corporations merging with gov't to run society.   

       So don't be used my friend for others political and financial gains, we need to learn how to critically think.......not that i am great at it but i have taken a journey because my society was no longer making sense in what they were saying.   Also by no means am i correct on all my assertions, after all how can i know the inner thoughts and motives of corporations and gov't.   If you follow the money though that is generally what is happening, in fact natives in the west have less access to tax payer funded services than minorities and refugee's............hell in Canada my aunt was told that to her face lol.   Sad state of affairs.

text:
Here's a little constructive pushback against both sides of this. Humour can fail and be disrespectful and still be a worthwhile enterprise. It frequently does, in fact. The idea of hating someone's acting so much that you would generalise to a hatred of their race is a potentially funny joke, with the target being the idiocy of the idea that anyone would think that's a reasonable way to act. 
The problem is that that joke wouldn't have been broadcast or have met with this kind of positive reception if it had been any other race.

Every single tweeter suffers from envy. The modern word is "hater": someone who is resentful and envious of others success, and who wish that they could be in that persons' place, but secretly, so they toss barbs at the object of their jealousy.
 .What a miserable state of affairs to be in. If you can't be happy for somebody else, you can't be happy for yourself either. You'll find fault in everything, everyone.
None of the celebrities warranted their disparaging comments.

author: mike O

text: You guys are killing me. Your philosophy that racism is only applicable to certain races is, ironically, racist. The concept of racism does not exclude any race, nor does it make any mention of any particular race. Take a step back and look at the argument, don‚Äôt look at the situation as a white person or as a black person. Don‚Äôt say ‚Äúwe whites,‚Äù or ‚Äúus blacks,‚Äù and try to rid yourself of any bias you may have. Everyone is unique and special and it is insulting for him/her to be grouped into a derogatory statement (or treated unjustly) merely based on the color of their skin.
author: Ultra Lord

text: Ultra Lord these people are idiots and looking for an excuse to be racist trash, it‚Äôs as simple as that. I don‚Äôt get why they call it reverse racism. It‚Äôs just straight up racism.
author: mike O

text: mike O I try not to take offense where offense is not intended. I believe the people we are debating mean well, however I am offended by whoever said ‚ÄúI hate white people.‚Äù I believe the short term for reverse racism is ‚Äúracism directed towards a majority.‚Äù Why it is called reverse-racism beats me, as racism occurs everywhere towards all races. It worries me whenever people fiddle with definitions and concepts to fit their own agenda.
author: Ultra Lord

text:
Ultra Lord they don‚Äôt mean well at all. Trust me on that, and their way of thinking is dangerous. I get what reverse racism is supposed to be, it‚Äôs just dumb and doesn‚Äôt make sense. They‚Äôre basically implying that racism only counts against black people as a definition. Shows how self absorbed and whacked from reality they are. 

I don‚Äôt get upset because it doesn‚Äôt do anything, but when trash like her tries to justify being racist I put them in their place. Sometimes I wonder if they‚Äôre actually that crazy to believe the crap they say or if they‚Äôre just looking for any excuse they can find to try and get payback to white people and just play a victim
author: mike O

text: mike O I do agree with a lot of what your saying. But look man if you really want to change someone‚Äôs mind about something, and help that person understand what you believe is just, then always confront the situation with love and peace. Be willing to listen to that person and seriously consider what they are saying. Then, maybe, just maybe, they will show you the same respect and actually listen, thus increasing the likelihood of them changing their mind. Don‚Äôt hurl insults or spread hate because no progress can be made then, and everyone is left feeling hateful and irritated.

text:
Why is it fine to say ‚ÄúI hate white people‚Äù, when it is not okay to say the same but for another skin color? It‚Äôs not even racist because it is designated to just a skin color and not even a race of people. I think most people these days are actually so ignorant, stereotypical, ‚Äúracist‚Äù,  and rude. I think all types of humor definitely have a place. But I know in America that that tweet wouldn‚Äôt have been shown if it was about a different skin color, which is stereotypical and hateful. I use quotes to imply that racism is actually something else entirely, but is now very watered down and misconstrued to allow ignorant and entitled people to make false claims that can‚Äôt be argued with logic because they are not based in logic. 

I guess I‚Äôm sorry if you were just trying to look at potentially funny comments. I don‚Äôt mean to ruin anyone‚Äôs day. And I‚Äôm willing to discuss what I just previously stated if they wish to respond and I see the response. And to clarify the only things I said negatively were about people who are rude, stereotypical, and stupid. But I‚Äôm sure this comment will have arguments. 
And people if you think you actually experience hate and racism then you are grossly discrediting people who were literally murdered in millions and or enslaved by others simply on their race. But most people decide that because they share some common trait with someone who was once subjugated for their race and treated awfully, that they are entitled to some compensations or different treatment, which is again, ‚Äúracist‚Äù... damn I need to just go to sleep

text:
CheapVids ftw First of all, I'd like to throw a cheap jab in here and remind you that humans have not been around since the beginning of time. In fact, humans as we know them have only existed for about 0.0000005% of the time the universe has existed. Now, in regards to your racist hypocratic comment, yes, you can in fact be racist to white people. And yea, you're right, white people have been racist to pretty much every race, including their own, throughout history. What you're forgetting (or never knew) is that throughout history literally EVERY other race has also been racist to literally EVERY other race. Just because white people enslaved black people in the United States doesn't mean they were the only slave owners throughout history. White people have actually, historically, been enslaved significantly more than black people.

You can't use history to make excuses for racism. Racism is bad period, no matter what race it's against, including whites. Saying it's ok to be racist to white people because they've been racist in the past is like saying all people who have descended from Nazis should be slaughtered in a genocide because their ancestors did it to Jews. Just because their ancestors did it doesn't make it ok to do it to them.

text:
Yeah, it's not "black" that's offensive, that would be acceptable. It's "BlackIE" that would be offensive, just as whiteY and white-bread are offensive. These words are racist in that they insinuate that all black/white people share whatever trait is being discussed (talking in the movie theater/clapping when planes land). 

Make sense?

text: Honestly, I find that more and more people, any colour really, seem to be dividing themselves on purpose, filling their own heads with preconceptions about each other's cultures instead of approaching it with an open mind and willing to learn something new from each other. If you want to help get rid of racism and stereotypes, start with yourself as well as others. Call it out when it happens, but don't practice it yourself, big or small, bottom line, otherwise you're doing the very thing that you claim you're against. This wasn't directed towards you by the way, it was just a general viewpoint on the subject. Cheers!

Access to jobs, education, healthcare, and even beauty standards all privilege the white experience, so there‚Äôs no real way for white people to face oppression for their race from people of color.
author: Danielle Marie Shillingford

text:
Danielle Marie Shillingford They way you're talking makes it seem like you think racism is equivalent to slavery. It's not. Here is the definition of racism.   

Racism
Noun 
prejudice, discrimination, or antagonism directed against someone of a different race based on the belief that one's own race is superior.
 
Any race can be racist to any race. An Asian person can tell an Native American person that Native Americans are disgusting. A Latino waiter can refuse to take the order of a white person because he is white. A black teacher can deny education to an Indian student because they believe Indians are inferior to blacks. These are all examples of racism that any person of any race could participate in. Anyone can be racist, regardless of their race.

text: I'm black and yeah I hate the double standard too. I think about it all the time. But it shouldn't be an "Us Vs. Them" mindset. I think the reason it's acceptable to make jokes about white people but not to black people is because both racism and slavery, hard to really explain but yeah it's kinda shitty.
author: Amier Lane

text: Slavery isn‚Äôt a justification for a double standard. You were never a slave, you never lived under Jim Crowe and I was never a slave holder and neither were my ancestors. Everyone in my family as far back as we can track were farmers and poor except me and my siblings. Consequences dished out to a whole race because a very small minority of people with the same pigment owned slaves over 100 years ago isn‚Äôt just. It‚Äôs like equating guilt to a child for his fathers crimes too. Unjust things have happened to every race by the other throughout history. Equality of opportunity for the individual is all that should matter. White people need to quit being guilt stricken self hating saps and black people need to forgive, drop it and accept responsibility for themselves. Because nobody‚Äôs going nowhere and fanning the flames and conflating things does no good whatsoever. We‚Äôre stuck with each other and we should all have the similarity‚Äôs in that we‚Äôre all Americans and what we all hold true is freedom.
author: JESSE D

text: JESSE D Like I said, I couldn't really explain what I meant, sorry if you didn't get that. Of course I wasn't a slave and I know you weren't a slaveholder. Slavery ended over 400 years ago so that was an irrelevant thing to say. But again, I wasn't making white people seem bad here at all. I agree with many of your points, it would be best to move on from the darkness, but racism isn't going away anytime soon and we can't just ignore our dark past in fear of repeating it. Trying love is the best way to go with the problems in the world but many people wouldn't try it at all. I appreciate you taking the time to voice your opinion.
author: Amier Lane

text: Go through 459 years of slavery, hundreds of more years of civil rights violations, and still be prejudiced against into current day. Then and only then can you say ‚Äúdouble standard ‚Äú. A double standard requires two equal things to be treated alike, yet one is treated differently. I don‚Äôt remember when the equal treatment happened. Don‚Äôt use some idiots tweet to justify your hatred. Are you looking for a reason to finally say the N - word? The celebrity handled it well by saying ‚Äúall of us?‚Äù It‚Äôs how I feel when I meet people who have misconceptions about people they‚Äôve never met and only get info from news and media. How could you hate a race and not know one person of that race? Exactly... ‚Äúall of us?‚Äù

text:
Tra Sco I prefer calling anybody who hates people of another race (because of their race) a racist, and then calling what you called racism "institutionalized racism" or something to that effect. It's annoying when most people in a comments section, for example, agree that racism is bad, but then get stuck arguing about terminology and definitions (let's ignore the fact that I'm literally doing that now lol). 

Most people don't use the word racism to mean prejudice + power (as you would in an academic institution or research paper), they use it to mean "hatred towards and/or unfair treatment towards a certain race", regardless of power. Instead of trying to make people use academic terminology, I think we should just accept the common usage of the word. A term like institutionalized racism is much more intuitive to understand. 

To be honest, I'd love it if people used racism to mean prejudice plus power. I just don't think it's going to happen any time soon in the States, and I think it's better to focus on things we agree on (like prejudice being a bad thing, and prejudice plus power being even worse) than try to make the majority use academic terms and definitions.
author: A. Neufeld

text:
So why can a black comedian get away with white people jokes but not the other way around? This is due to the concept of ‚Äúprivileged vs. underprivileged.‚Äù It‚Äôs acceptable for the underprivileged to make jokes about the privileged but not the other way around.

Here is an example. Let‚Äôs talk about short guys vs tall guys. If you‚Äôre a short guy, you‚Äôre at a disadvantage versus tall guys because we all know that tall guys tend to have more success with women and tall guys command more power in a room. So in this scenario, short guys are the ‚Äúunderprivileged‚Äù and tall guys are the ‚Äúprivileged.‚Äù This is why it‚Äôs usually acceptable for a short guy to make fun of a tall guy. The logic is that if you‚Äôre speaking from the perspective of the disadvantaged, then you should be allowed to make jokes because it sorta evens things out. But a tall guy would be considered a cruel jerk if he pokes fun at a short guy because tall guys already have the advantages. So jokes coming from the ‚Äúprivileged‚Äù seem unfair because the privileged already have the upper hand.

In our current society, black people are considered the ‚Äúunderprivileged‚Äù and white people are considered the ‚Äúprivileged.‚Äù This is why black people can make racist jokes all day but white people can‚Äôt. Y‚Äôall may not agree with this concept but it is what it is.

text: slipping freedoms they probably did, or they just googled how power structures works. It's a complex concept. I'm in university and have studied how privilege and oppression works in society. You can't be "racist"to white people because white peoples have never, and aren't oppressed based on their race. When you say mean things to white people, it's called "discrimination based on race." People think discrimination based on race is the exact thing as racism, but racism is discrimination based on race and as well includes more complex things then that, Racism is connected to privilege and oppression. discriminating a white person and calling them a "whitey" is discriminatory and it is very rude and definitely NOT okay. But it doesn't have the same effect in society as calling a black person the N word, because white people arent oppressed and being called a "whitey" doesn't effect their privilege in life, it's basically just a form a mean bullying. Wheras when you do the same to a black person, it will effect their privilege in life because they are CURRENTLY and have historically been oppressed in society and it's a much different situation. It's hard to explain online as it's very complex and complicated, but you are welcome to ask me for links to read up on it if you are interested in learning more! (:

text:
slipping freedoms The dictionary is actually not the best reliable source for information. I'll try to explain the best I can, forgive me if my grammar is off, english is second language and translate is helping me (i'm white and from canada but grew up very french if you were curious) 

The dictionary is just a book written by white people a LONG time ago to provide a consolidated source to have basic general meanings for words. The dictionary isn't written to apply social context and even modern speech. You can only write down so much information about language. Dictionary authors and people who study communication/english and writing even say that words and context are forever changing and a dictionary is only a very bare basic snap shot of basic meaning that was popular at the time. The oxfords dictionary them selves even admit that context and words are shaped by progression and society and they update the dictionary sometimes. 

Words have multiple meanings and contexts in languages and change through out time, 
so no, the dictionary definition of "racism" is not a current snapshot of its meaning as it was created a very long time ago by white peoples anyways. History of race oppression has shaped the word.... it's hard to explain. I hope that makes sense.
author: Mango Peach

text: slipping freedoms That definition isn't necessarily out right "wrong" as there is no right or wrong , life isn't black and white. But context does matter and words and language shape them selves. For instance, words like "sick, gnarly, wild, lit, " are now popular words that have different contextual meaning. "Haha dude that's lit." the dictionary says lit means fire, but now a days society (in younger generation mostly) has shaped the word to mean "awesome, fun, wild, exiting...." and ect. Context and history matters and that's why the dictionary is not a reliable source!
author: Mango Peach

text:
I feel like it‚Äôs important to know the context of some of these before you go can call it ‚Äúracist‚Äù:
Scarlett Johansson‚Äôs tweet: So this was around the time when Ghost in the Shell (aka a JAPANESE movie starring a white woman) was released. If you remember, she received quite a lot of backlash for this, but many came to her defense. A news website (can‚Äôt remember who it is atm) released an article (written by a white person) defending her stating that Asians can‚Äôt be cast in movies because they aren‚Äôt expressive/don‚Äôt have ‚Äòa diverse set of facial expressions‚Äô and so, that‚Äôs why Hollywood hires white people to play asians instead - which is CLEARLY very racist. The tweet was a response to that. Does it make it any less mean or rude? I mean no, but that‚Äôs the whole point of this segment right? 

Chadwick & Tom‚Äôs tweets: I mean... if you really think these are racist well honey, you might need to chill out a bit!! I mean Chadwick is a bit white a white name, what‚Äôs so wrong with that??? The person just said they thought he‚Äôd have a more African-sounding name. Not sure what how that‚Äôs racist against white people. 
And Tom‚Äôs tweet.. I mean white people are literally the only people i‚Äôve ever witnessed applaud when a plane lands so they weren‚Äôt lying. These statements are NOT  racist, prejudice or are discriminative towards white people. If you think they are, then you need to take a step back and think about the fact that while you believe these are forms of racism, POC have to deal with being called terrorists, rapists, being killed by the cops etc 

(i apologize for any typos or grammar errors, if any)

author: neocultureten

text:
First, let me just begin by saying, reverse racism is an oxymoron. It's either racist or it's not. The target of the racism doesn't determine the validity of the racism.

Second, I'm not sure I follow. You understand the comments were offensive, but you feel people are unjust in expressing their offense because it's not equal? So, you're going to make things more equal in the future by making them less equal today? I think we can both agree "I hate black people" will never be on Kimmel's Mean Tweets, right? 

So, the cure for racism is to be openly racist against white people? Great idea.
author: atheist28403

text:
atheist28403 i‚Äôm not sure how you gathered all that on what i said but okay ...

For comments like these, they‚Äôre not on the same level. Poc are discriminated against wayyyyy wayyyy more, so a few comments on this video about white people vs the real life crap poc have to deal with are incomparable, which is what people don‚Äôt understand. I never said anything about it being unjust, it‚Äôs just that people are getting butthurt at this small handful of comments and trying to use it to say it‚Äôs just as bad, when it really isn‚Äôt
author: neocultureten

text:
"...a few comments on this video about white people vs the real life crap poc have to deal with are incomparable..."

So, you are saying that no white people have a right to complain about anti-white racism openly displayed on a national platform because there are some openly racist white people out there. Obviously, there are some openly racist people of other colors too (hence, why we're having this conversation). I've never oppressed anyone, why should I be asked to tolerate someone being openly racist toward all white people? 

Again, changing the target of racism isn't going to make the future less racist.

text:
Hmm, I wonder if it is far easier for a 'I hate black people' statement to be construed as racism because of an actual history of systemic hatred, exclusion and subjugation by white people towards black people. 

It's almost like there are still a whole tonne of racists out there who disguise their racist beliefs towards black people with cowardly ambiguity, and so it is entirely reasonable to assume that such statements come from a place of actual racism. 

And, bear with me here, because I know that this is mind-blowing, it's almost like white people in the U.S. have never and will never face the types of discrimination that black people still experience even today, and so having to read 'I hate white people' on the internet is really nothing to clutch your pearls over when there's a far lesser chance that it comes from someone who genuinely sees you as subhuman because of the color of your skin.

But then again, you can lazily take it at face value, and act as if 'I hate white people' and 'I hate black people' has the exact same connotations in the context of the real world and its history. This is the internet, a rampant haven for white fragility after all.

text:
@Lachy Roberts, 'White fragility' 'it's almost like white people in the U.S.'

I don't know who you are, I have never met you in my life...yet you seem to have 'me' all figured out in your head.....based on my skin colour. I have never hurt you,  I have never hurt anyone, I have never uttered a racist word or even thought a racist thought...yet you are convinced that I am a hate filled racist....based on my skin colour. 

I was born in the very late 20th century, I have never owned a slave, I have never been a slave. I have never had any sort of involvement in slavery in any way, shape or form. You were born in either the late 20th century or early 21st century...you have never owned a slave, you have never been a slave, you have as much idea as I do of what it would be like to be a slave...from movies and books and heresay...stories passed down through generations.

Yet you think that you have a right to demand that I experience what it is that people experienced hundreds of years ago...why...because you think that it would make you feel better to see me suffer......because of my skin colour. You demand that I experience and 'understand' racism today...why? Because you think that it will make YOU feel better and once again you make that demand based on my skin colour. You demand that I make reparation for what happened before either of us were even born! Based on my skin colour.

Where is the remotest logic in that.....seriously...think about it. Actually stop and 'think'.

YOU are the hatred filled one. YOU are the racist. YOU are propagating a lie against innocent people. YOU are the problem and the problem is ALL in your head. People are INDIVIDUALS, stop judging them based on their skin colour, you are doing exactly what you accuse others of doing. Your 'philosophy' is pure insanity and makes ZERO logical sense, your hatred is utterly misguided and delusional and I thank god that most people are actually rational beings that can see the utter insanity of holding someone responsible for something that they have no control over, weren't even born.

I am sorry if you were subjected to racism somewhere...but I will be damned if I am going to let you shove the blame for that onto me. I could no more have stopped any such thing then I could have stopped any other injustice or crime so completely out of my ability to do so.

So comment away with some other illogical delusions, I will not read or reply, I have no time or respect for people so lacking in rational thought and reason and so filled with irrational racist hatred.

author: Peyton Cox

text:
Angry: Sorry, I should have included all of the liberals I haven't met, but that I have seen on TV as well. 

As there have been no scientific studies (that I'm aware of) on the propensity of liberals (as a social class) to hold tight to double standards, I have to use my own experiences/observations. As this is an easily recognized pattern across each encounter I've had with self-professed liberals, my experience (i.e. my reality) indicates that this is a common feature among most members of the group. Either that or I've stumbled across the biggest statistical anomaly since Robert Ramos was playing ball in the 70s. 

My lack of faith (like most Atheists I've met) stems from an inability to recognize evidence of a deity. In other words, I have never experienced any type of divine incident or seen any proof (anecdotal evidence) that any religion is correct in its statements of faith. 

Also, you should know (before continuing to embarrass yourself), "such evidence" is how scientific research begins. You recognize a pattern in the environment, you develop hypotheses as to why these things happen, and then you methodically test your hypotheses to determine their likelihood and explanatory power. By the way, as a college professor, two-thirds of my job is dedicated to conducting social research for publication in scientific journals.
author: atheist28403

text:
atheist28403 "my experience" & "statistical anomaly"....

Definition of statistics: information based on a study of the number of times something happens or is present, or other numerical facts.

Anecdotal evidence: evidence collected in a casual or informal manner and relying heavily or entirely on personal testimony. When compared to other types of evidence, anecdotal evidence is generally regarded as limited in value due to a number of potential weaknesses. anecdotal evidence does not qualify as scientific evidence, because its nature prevents it from being investigated by the scientific method.Accurate determination of whether an anecdote is typical requires statistical evidence.

That fact that you think anecdotal evidence is somehow statistical, & not that it is statistical evidence that is required to validate it, means that right off the bat you've created an informal fallacy for yourself.

Also, you should know (before continuing to embarrass yourself) such evidence is not how scientific research begins, it is how the realisation that scientific research is required begins. Furthermore, psychologists have found that due to cognitive bias people are more likely to remember notable or unusual examples rather than typical examples. Thus, even when accurate, anecdotal evidence is not necessarily representative of a typical experience.

By the way, if you are indeed a college professor, you should be sacked asap. As you're rather strange interpretation of what qualifies as valid information, is confirmation of blatant bias towards specific results at best, & obvious lack of understanding of the scientific method at worst.
author: The Angry Gentleman

text:
"Also, you should know (before continuing to embarrass yourself) such evidence is not how scientific research begins, it is the realization that scientific research is required begins."

Which is how scientific research begins, genius.

You should tell that last part to my department chair, he'd get a kick out of it!
author: atheist28403

text: atheist28403 good man. Pick the semantics part of my comment to debate, as it seems you're aware you don't have a leg to stand on in literally any other aspect ;)
author: The Angry Gentleman

text:
Sorry, that was the only part of your comment worth debating. 

I mostly agree with the definitions (statistics and anecdotal evidence) you plagiarized from a quick google search, except that a scientific study need not be developed (or ran) in order to collect and statistically analyze data (this is how we collect sports-related statistics). As I said, I am not aware of any studies that have explored this construct (double standards) across political groups. As such, my experiences are the only evidence I have to go on. I guess you would need to know who Robert Ramos is to understand the analogy. 

"That fact that you think anecdotal evidence is somehow statistical, & not that it is statistical evidence that is required to validate it, means that right off the bat you've created an informal fallacy for yourself."

First, you need to proofread that sentence, it makes little sense. Second, you most certainly can statistically analyze anecdotal evidence. That said, statistical analysis does not make it "scientific", nor did I claim that it could.
author: atheist28403

text:
See, you say you agree with the definitions, yet you clearly do not adhere to them..
"my experiences are the only evidence I have to go on" that may be, but lack of more information does not make the flawed information you do have access to suddenly valid.

I never said you couldn't statistically analyse anecdotal evidence, I said you NEED to supplement such evidence with statistical analysis in order to validate it, while you seem to think that anecdotal evidence is inherently statistical in the same vain that empirical evidence is. Which is false.

I honestly feel sad for the students you teach going out into the world thinking anecdotal evidence on it's own holds weight in any way shape or form. See, your not actually arguing with me (you'll notice at no point have I interjected my own opinion into this), your arguing with one of the fundamental facets of the scientific method. Because as you pointed out, I've just been 'plagiarising' the dictionary definitions of these things. Not even attempting to paraphrase or reword them to fit my argument. Because its not necessary. It's plain for all to see that you are not adhereing to the scientific method. & when one does not adhere to that method, conclusions such as yours are inherently flawed.
author: The Angry Gentleman

text:
First, I said I "mostly" agree with the definitions you plagiarised. As I had stated, you don't need to run an experiment to collect data that can be statistically analyZed. Nearly any data (that can be compared mathematically) can be statistically analyZed.

"I never said you couldn't statistically analyZe anecdotal evidence, I said you NEED to supplement such evidence with statistical analysis in order to validate it..."

So, if I statistically analyZe anecdotal evidence, I need supplement the evidence with additional statistical analyses? Great job arguing that point.

"...while you seem to think that anecdotal evidence is inherently statistical..." Inherently statistical? What does that even mean? Maybe you should find another definition of statistics that isn't so difficult for you to understand.

Lastly, you'rE obviously not one of my students. If they don't know the difference between "your" and "you're" before they enter my class, they damn sure do by the end of the semester. As such, you have no idea what I teach my students. The fact that you believe I could get away with talking out of my ass to college students speaks volumes about your own education, or rather lack thereof. Well, that and the pride you take in your plagiarism of flawed definitions.
